ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Solid foundational understanding of political philosophy.
I learned about Western political philosophy and developed skills to think and write about philosophical questions, incorporating evidence from a variety of authors.

Wide scope of almost every major western political-philosophical discipline. Extra emphasis on Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, and Rawls. Improved understanding of how arguments work in political philosophy.
Acquaintance with classics in western moral/political philosophy and an understanding of their underlying historical/logical connections
Ability to think critically about philosophical thoughts and apply them to contemporary issues
A great overview of major ideas in political philosophy.

This course was a great survey-type course, because about a day to a week was spent on each major philosopher without going terribly deeply into any one. This is also a helpful course to get an introduction to philosophy, because it was helpful in learning the skill of thinking analytically about philosophy specifically.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish we would have had more discussions in this class and possibly shorter lectures prior to the readings, which were dense and sometimes hard to understand without any prior knowledge of the author's argument. The few times that we did have pre recorded lectures and then discussions during our class time, I felt much more engaged with the content and left with a better understanding of the author's perspective, interpretations of the work, and real world implications.

Way too many readings - we're talking hundreds of pages a week some weeks. By the end of the semester, it's just impossible to maintain that level of time for readings that will be summarized in the lecture anyway. It would be a lot easier to do less reading more deeply in order to figure out what we should actually focus on in the class.

The final exam was incredibly hard to study for and is curved on an unpredictable scale.

Strength: great selection of texts and interpretation by Prof Pogge
Weakness: would have benefited a dedicated time for live discussions
Great range of thinks covered although it was somewhat overwhelming to do so many in such a short period of time
The main strength is Prof Pogge! He is extremely knowledgeable and always available to discuss any of the material during office hours.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lectures always had detailed slides, and Professor Pogge provided incredibly fast and thorough feedback to every assignment.
The opening up of some sessions exclusively to discussion helped greatly

There weren't any discussion meetings in the course until the last month of the semester, and I think they were very helpful in really understand the course material. I think that these discussion times would be a great addition to the course as a scheduled part of the syllabus.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes

I probably would not recommend this course to another student. I think there are probably more engaging classes that cover very similar material in a more effective way and even move beyond western thinking.
I don't know if I would recommend those courses with Professor Pogge. You can just google him to find out why.
Yes, it's an intellectually formative experience if you put in the work
Absolutely- it is a great introduction to philosophy

YES! If you are interested in the material and ready to do the weekly readings, you will enjoy the course! If you take it, don't hesitate to email Prof Pogge and meet with him during office hours. That's the most helpful part!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Occasional discussions
We had a few discussions throughout the semester, but almost always lectures.
A few live discussions
Some sessions were dedicated to discussion rather than lecture
